```{r}
# Function that returns a result upon calling

  return(result)
}

######### Scripting (or programming) with R#######

########## if else #######

# if(condition){
#   do something
# }
# else{
#   do the alternative
# }

a <- 10
if(a == 1){
  print("a is equal 1")
} else {
  print("a is not equal 1")
}

# grade A: 8-10
# 
# grade B: 6-7
# 
# grade C:4-5
#
# grade D: 0-3

grade <- 5 # out of 10

# Here look at the usage of "if else"
if(grade >= 8 & grade <= 10){
  print("Student1 got grade A")
} else if(grade >= 6 & grade <=7){
  print("Student1 got grade B")
} else if(grade >= 4 & grade <= 5){
  print("Student1 got grade C")
} else{
  print("Student1 for grade D")
}

####### while #####

# while(condition){
#   execute some action
# }

# This will start an infinite loop
# a <- 10
# while(a < 11){
#   print("a is less than 11")
# }

## Here look at the usage of 1) paste() functioon and 2) break

a <- 10
while(a < 20){
  print(paste(a, " is less than 20"))
  a <- a+1
  if(a == 20){
    print("Now a is equal to 20")
    break
    print("I have not obeying the break function") # when break is applied, this line will not be executed.
  }
}
######### for loop #####
a <- 1:10
b <- c("a","b","c","d","e")

# looping through the contents of a vector directly
for(i in b){
  print(i)
}

# looping through sequential numbers. In some programming language you have to define the initial value and the increment in this line.
for(i in 1:5){
  print(i)
}

# for a bit better understanding
for(i in 1:5){
  print(paste("the value of i is", i))
}

# looping through the contents of a vector using indexing
for(i in 1:length(b)){
  print(b[i])
}

# Look at this piece of code to understand the nested loop and the change of the values of i and j
for(i in 1:5){
  for(j in 6:10){
    print(paste("Now i is", i, "and j is", j))
  }
}

# further usage of foor loop
a <- c("a1","a2","a3","a4","a5","a6")
b <- c("b1","b2","b3","b4","b5","b6")
c <- c("c1","c2","c3","c4","c5","c6")

df <- data.frame(a,b,c,stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

for(colVlaue in 1:ncol(df)){
  for(rowValue in 1:nrow(df)){
    print(df[rowValue,colVlaue])
  }
}
# ...... and using if clause inside the for loop

for(colValue in 1:ncol(df)){
  for(rowValue in 1:nrow(df)){
    if(df[rowValue,colValue] == "c6"){
      print(c(rowValue, colValue))
    }
  }
}


```
